newsitem.title: GERMANY: German DAX ends bourse trade at higher levels.
newsitem.headline: German DAX ends bourse trade at higher levels.

text.p: German shares ended bourse trade on Wednesday at higher levels, reaping the benefits of a higher close on Wall Street overnight, but with sentiment muted by the weaker dollar.
The DAX-30 index of leading German shares ended 25.77 points, 0.77 percent, higher at 3,353.45 after trying to catch up with Tuesday's post-bourse rally.
June DAX futures were a point higher at 3,374.0 early on, but they fell sharply over the session before recovering to stand at 3,364 points, down nine.
With turnover low and even 1996 result details from industrial giant Daimler-Benz AG, maker of Mercedes vehicles, failing to excite the market, trade was firmly range-bound over the session.
The DAX index was unable to breake out of a range between 3,345 and 3,368 points over the session.

Dealers said new result details released from Daimler-Benz were viewed positively but not with the same enthusiasm that greeted recent figures from BMW. Upgrades were nonetheless expected to result from an analyst meeting later today.
Daimler's shares ended bourse at 138.15 points, up 1.25 marks, having earlier reached an all-time of 142.40.
Dealers said a move by the group to issue 1.1 billion marks in mandatory convertible notes to strengthen its capital base was not being seen positively.

Drugs group Schwarz Pharma, which late Tuesday said group net profits rose 14.4 percent in 1996 and further a profit growth was expected in 1997, rose 3.50 marks to 137.00, but ended the day down 2.80 marks at 130.
Luxury carmaker Porsche AG was among the chief winners over the session after U.S. investment bank Lehman Brothers urged its clients to switch to it from other car stocks.
Porsche ended the day up 120 marks, 5.91 percent, at 1,150 marks.
